fields.description:
Similar to staging or discarding single files or hunks, it would be great to be able to stash only selected files or even single hunks.

This can be done with "git stash save --patch". Would be great to have this git feature exposed in the SourceTree UI as well.
fields.summary: Stashing on file or hunk level a.k.a. "git stash save --patch"

fields.description: Ocassionally, just after doing a commit or a push Sourcetree crashes. I attach an exception log.
fields.summary: Crash after commit

fields.description:
I'm working with a legacy Mac project that provides a custom Finder icon for the .bundle via an "Icon\r" file -- yes, that's a file whose name contains 5 characters: the first 4 are "Icon" and the last one is a carriage return (0x0D). It's a special filename convention... and SourceTree doesn't seem to like it.

See the attached .dmg. The .menu bundle within it contains such an icon. Try working with that .menu in a repo working copy: try adding it, committing it, etc.... well, you can commit if you can add it. Then try deleting it either from the repo or then from the Finder (via SourceTree's commands to do so).

It doesn't happen. Can't work with it because somehow it looks like it's treating the filename as "Iconr"... but I'm not sure if that's just what's being displayed or how the actual internal git command strings are beiing formulated, but either way it's not right.
fields.summary: Cannot properly work with "Icon\r" files.

fields.description:
SourceTree does not ignore the changes in Submodule when the option 'ignore' is added to .gitmodules file:
{noformat}
[submodule "asubmodule"]
        path = asubmodule
        url = git@github.com:test/test.git
        ignore = all 
{noformat}
fields.summary: SourceTree does not respect the 'ignore' flag in the .gitmodules file

fields.summary: Crash adding working copy

fields.description:
I've got some repositories on a slow usb2 HD connected to a slow server connection to a slow internal network connected to a slow internet connection.

When I launch sourcetree, the bookmarks window shows that it is trying to check the state of these repositories. Trying to access too many things at once on this network/internet connection fails many times before I can do anything. 

Once I can get the project I want open in sourcetree, if there happens to be any activity in the bookmark window, about 3 seconds later my history log view in the main window goes blank and I start getting error messages (will update with real messages) like "too many files open", "corrupt object", and others. The repositories on the server have not actually been corrupted as far as I can tell.

I think if there was a way to keep all my bookmarks but tell them "go to sleep and don't check the status of anything until I intentionally wake you up" I would be able to avoid these problems.
fields.summary: Ability to hibernate/deactivate certain bookmarks.

fields.description:
I've seen this a couple times, usually when closing a repository window. But I haven't been able to get it to reproduce reliably so I'm not 100% sure what the repro steps would be. But given the message in the crash log, maybe you can resolve it without a repro.

The crash reports:

```
Crashing on exception: Cannot remove an observer <STCommitAndFileStatusPanelViewController 0x7f9038c57e90> for the key path "useFixedWithCommitFont" from <NSUserDefaults 0x618000058780> because it is not registered as an observer.
```

I'll attach the crash log.
fields.summary: Crash from exception: STCommitAndFileStatusPanelViewController and useFixedWithCommitFont

fields.description:
1. Checkout a repo from an Xcode repository managed by the latest version of OS X Server.
2. Open the project in Source Tree (may need to refresh it via cmd+R).
3. Four prompts for credentials to access the System keychain should appear in succession regardless of whether valid credentials are supplied or not.
4. Notice similar log messages in the Console app:

7/20/14 1:26:45.325 PM launchservicesd\[74\]: Application App:"SourceTree" asn:0x0-10c10c pid:5781 refs=8 @ 0x7f80e9762090 tried to be brought forward, but isn't in fPermittedFrontApps ( ( "LSApplication:0x0-0x134134 pid=7186 "SecurityAgent"")), so denying. : LASSession.cp #1481 SetFrontApplication() q=LSSession 100006/0x186a6 queue

7/20/14 1:26:45.325 PM WindowServer\[101\]: \[cps/setfront\] Failed setting the front application to SourceTree, psn 0x0-0x10c10c, securitySessionID=0x186a6, err=-13066

7/20/14 1:26:45.488 PM com.apple.SecurityServer\[15\]: Problem opening rules file "/etc/authorization": No such file or directory

Of note, usage of the "/etc/authorization" is [deprecated in Mavericks|http://www.dssw.co.uk/blog/2013-10-26-authorization-rights-and-mavericks/].
fields.summary: Continuous prompts to authenticate access to keychain

fields.description:
When I have unstaged files in the unstaged list (main view or commit view), and I click on a file that is new (question mark icon next to it), generates an error and does not add / stage the file.

Error Box:
git -c diff.mnemonicprefix=false -c core.quotepath=false -c credential.helper=sourcetree rm -q -f -- app/assets/javascripts/sessions.js.coffee 
fatal: pathspec 'app/assets/javascripts/sessions.js.coffee' did not match any files
Completed with errors, see above

If I go to terminal add do git add . the file is then staged and can then be committed.
fields.summary: Staging new files reports error

fields.description:
When finishing a feature via git flow, there is an option to delete the feature branch afterwards. It does not delete a tracked remote feature branch though.

We push local feature branches if they live longer than a day. As they are not deleted by git flow, they often stack up on the server. It would be helpful if git flow would delete the tracked remote branch too.
fields.summary: Git Flow: Finish Feature: Delete Remote Branch

fields.description:
Sometimes I have to compare different commits and branches. I know that I can do this in the log view by selecting two commits with Cmd, but this is very annoying.

I am using also SmartGit which has some features which I am missing at Sourcetree:

# In SmartGit I can select a tag or branch in the repository view and use the context menu (reveal commit) to jump to a tag or commit. After this operation the corresponding the corresponding commit will be selected in the log view.
# After this operation I can select a different branch and use the context menu "compare against selected commit". This is really helpful. In SourceTree this operation is not possible. Currently you can only select a branch, then you have to select the commit in the log view and the context menu allows only the diff against the current.
# The log view can be quite long, therefore a filtering of the log would be great. In SmartGit you can search also for tags in the commit view, this means if you want to diff to tags, you just have to use a corresponding search pattern. Afterwards the two tags can be selected in the filtered view (without annoying scrolling in the logs) and that is really easy.

I attached some screenshot to illustrate the behavior.
fields.summary: Filter log view and compare of branches

fields.description:
To reproduce:
# Clone a Mercurial repo.
# Change a file in the project
# Add a file to the project
# In the ST "Working Copy" view, tick the checkbox next to the newly added file
# Click "Shelve" on the toolbar
# The modification to the existing file is shelved, but the newly added file is not; it remains in the working copy.

I would expect the following behaviour:
* If the newly added file is ticked, it should be shelved
* Otherwise, it should remain in the working copy

The workaround is to either:
* Use some IDE feature to do the shelving (e.g. IDEA allows fine-grained control of what to shelve)
* Use the file system (e.g. Finder or command line) tools to move the file out of the project (not very handy because you have to remember where to put it back afterwards)
fields.summary: In Mercurial, untracked files are not shelved

fields.description:
When scrolling through the commit tree, the tree view frequently refreshes and changes the view to a different part of the tree from what I was viewing.

I haven't been able to nail down exactly where it defaults to after a refresh - seem to often be the commit which is currently highlighted, but today it was refreshing to a different place again.

Generally happens multiple times in a 30 second period - so much so that when I'm scrolling down to find a particular commit I can't actually view that commit and the surround tree because it keeps refreshing and changing the view.

This is incredibly frustrating and makes the tool close to unusable as my primary use is to check through the commit tree when looking at various branches being worked on by my dev team.
fields.summary: Tree view refresh changes which part of the tree is viewed

fields.description:
This is closely related to SRCTREE-2490, although the crash presented slightly differently this time. To reproduce, use exactly the same instructions as per SRCTREE-2490.

The crash looks identical to me except that I got this in syslog:
{{16/07/2014 14:05:41.296 spindump[31505]: SourceTree [874] didn't gather any samples due to audio running}}
however I did get a screenshot. Note that there was the expected huge pause before the 'mux_client_request_session' was printed while it waited to confirm the existing socket had indeed timed out. Once the info about labels had printed, the beach ball of death started spinning (i.e. I couldn't scroll down to see if there were any other messages there).

If I get it again without iTunes running I'll upload a crash log, however I haven't got time to deliberately reproduce it right now, sorry.
fields.summary: SourceTree crashes with git+ssh and ControlPersist

fields.description:
It is possible to get SourceTree into an infinite loop of authorisation prompts which continue even after the app has been force quit. Resolving requires 'ps -auxww | egrep -i sourcetree' and a kill -9 of all pids returned.

To reproduce:

1) Set up an SSH tunnel to a remote machine (may not be required to reproduce this, but explains why I was doing the next steps :) on port 80.
2) Open Bookmarks window.
3) Click 'Add Repository'.
4) Enter 'localhost:80' in Source Path / URL. (This is not the complete source path, but the user should be allowed to complete other fields and come back to this one.)
5) Click in Destination Path. An auth dialog appears (see attachment).
6) Click Cancel.

Expected behaviour: the dialog goes away and does not come back.
Actual behaviour: the dialog is recreated.

7) Quit SourceTree from the Dock menu.

Expected behaviour: SourceTree quits and takes the dialog with it.
Actual behaviour: NSBeep, and SourceTree stays running.

8) Force quit SourceTree.
9) Cancel the dialog.

Expected behaviour: the dialog goes away and does not come back, as the process that created is has been quit.
Actual behaviour: the dialog is recreated, as SourceTree has launched a background process that Force Quit does not touch. It is necessary to go to the command line as detailed at the start of this description in order to stop the relentless dialog onslaught.

The infinite loop should not occur. The user may realise they do not have the auth information, for example. In any case, it would be better to prompt once the user hits OK on the dialog, rather than as soon as the Source Path / URL field is defocused.
fields.summary: Infinite auth prompt loop when adding repository

fields.description:
I work with Unity, which means sometimes .prefab and .unity files get rather large. Although I have SourceTree set to not diff .unity and .prefab files, there are times when SourceTree does it anyway (for example in the commit window or in the stashed changes window).

Regardless of when it chooses to diff them or not, it would be great to have a global setting for a diff timeout. In other words, if SourceTree is taking longer than X seconds to diff something, it stops trying and doesn't show a diff for it.

As it stands right now, there are several times during my workday at which point SourceTree attempts to diff something larger than it should and locks up for 30+ seconds.
fields.summary: Have a diff timeout setting (in seconds) to prevent overlong lockups.

fields.description:
Check screenshot for more info.

The deletion icon seems to be blurry.
fields.summary: Blurry "deletion" icon in bookmarks view

fields.description: There is already an option when you finish a feature in git flow to remove the branch but that just happens locally.  It would be nice to be able to have that remove the remote branch as well.
fields.summary: Finish feature branch - delete remote

fields.description: The “Git Version” box in the Git preference is not following Apple HIG. It doesn’t use the metrics Interface Builder would recommend.
fields.summary: Git Version box in the Git preference is not following Apple HIG

fields.description:
to replicate go in the commit view and:
# go to treeview mode (I don't know if it's applicable to different view mode)
# uncheck the global checkbox on top, near (Pending files, sorted by path)
# check manually some files if the list (I checked an entire folder)
# click the commit button

It says that there is nothing to commit.

The workaround is to check again the global checkbox and unselect manually all the files that I don't want to commit.
fields.summary: Nothing to commit

fields.description:
Pressing cmd+backspace when typing in commit message input field causes "Confirm Remove Modified or Untracked Files?" dialog to appear, instead of standard mac os's action "delete last line".

This is quite annoying, because standard text input hotkey is overriden by something unrelated. I run into this quite often.
fields.summary: Pressing cmd+backspace in commit message input field brings up "Confirm Remove" dialog

fields.description: If you have a changed file from which you wish to commit some changes you can do this in by split view staging mode by staging some hunks, selecting the staged files, and then pressing commit on the menu or toolbar. However if you use my normal workflow and right click in the staging area the view is bounced into 'no staging' mode. (This is the actual bug, right?) The selection is correctly maintained, but any files which are partly staged become fully staged and will be commited as such.
fields.summary: It's now harder to commit some changes from a file (Git) compared with 1.8

fields.description:
http://screencast.com/t/tWOwtTTdGF

v1.9.5
fields.summary: Broken partial staging

fields.description:
I'm using git-svn in SourceTree.

(Preferences settings: System Git 2.0.1 from MacPorts)

When I open the 'push dialog', the first repository is a 'Subversion'.
Crash whenever I try to change the repository (e.g. 'origin').
fields.summary: Crash With git-svn in SourceTree 1.9.5.2

fields.description:
The app crashes on what appears to be a closing of a project/repository window while there's a diff going on.

In my case, I have a repo that has a binary library that keeps getting changed by the build process. It's the only change in the working copy.

Open the repo's window, and that changed library is selected, and on the right side of the window the detail of the change is automatically being displayed... and there are spinners showing the diff in progress.

If I wait until the diff completes (no more spinners), I can close the window no problem.  If however I close the window while things are spinning, it crashes.

It reproduces this way every time for me.

Crash log attached.
fields.summary: Crash when closing project window

fields.description:
Just like Stash, Github and other systems that support Pull Requests, it would be awesome for SourceTree to enable Crucible Reviews creation from the GUI in a similar fashion (i.e.: right click the branch that contains the changes and select "Create review in Crucible" - if the additional link was configured for the remote/account).

This way it could automatically pick the branching point to the head of that branch or even let me select commits from the UI to batch as a review and add that as content of the newly created review.
fields.summary: Create Crucible reviews from SourceTree just like Pull Requests in Stash

fields.description: As per http://git-scm.com/docs/git-commit (see: --allow-empty) there should be an option to allow empty git commits (a commit with a message and no body/changed files)
fields.summary: Allow empty commit

fields.description:
SourceTree's "Refresh Remote Status" is available both as a background task run every X minutes, or as a user-selectable action in the Repository menu. However, it functions mostly invisibly (unless and until it detects a status change): selecting it from the menu doesn't appear to do anything. Yes, there's a "Fetching" indicator in the window's status bar, but it vanishes quickly and leaves no indication behind as to whether the refresh worked or not.

I'm dealing with a remote, often slow server over a VPN, and I never know if a manually-invoked Refresh worked or failed (if the VPN is down or disconnected, Refresh gives me exactly the same response as if it's up).

I searched the Atlassian discussions regarding this and see that a lot of people are equally confused about this nearly invisible operation.

Improved visual feedback on refresh status would be most welcome... perhaps a persistent remote repository indicator in the status bar at the bottom of the window? It might have the remote's name and a status indicator, showing whether the last (or current) refresh is in progress, succeeded, or failed to contact the repository.
fields.summary: Better visual feedback for Repository > Refresh Remote Status

fields.description: Often, when a pull fails the 'Pulling Branch "master" from "origin"' dialog does not close and its 'close' button and 'show full output' toggle are greyed out. The only way to solve it is by quiting and re-opening SourceTree.
fields.summary: 'Pulling Branch "xxx" From "origin"' dialog does not close

fields.description:
The remote branch that's shown under the commit textarea is stuck on the wrong remote branch "tony.t/master" when the branch is tracking "origin/master". I've tried set the branch to track different remote branches, and even deleted and recreated the branch but it stays stuck on "tony.t/master".

Seth Foss responded to the following post, and ultimately suggested I file a bug here.

https://answers.atlassian.com/questions/290800/is-it-possible-to-modify-the-push-changes-immediately-option?page=1#comment-313217
fields.summary: "Push changes immediately" is stuck on the wrong branch

fields.description:
File change detection has degraded in 1.9.5

Prior to 1.9.5, SourceTree was very responsive in picking up changed files - as soon as the window was focused it would detect the changes.

However, this has deteriorated in 1.9.5 (which I installed only an hour ago).  Files aren't picked up as changed for an extended period of time (ten seconds or more).
fields.summary: File change detection has degraded in 1.9.5

If I open the repo with Sourcetree Windows (or another git client like the 2nd attachment), there isn't.

Step by step how to reproduce:

1) Do "Log Selected..." on a file
2) enable "Follow renamed files"
3) select two lines showing up after 2) is done
4) right part of the window show no diff/changes

fields.description:
Updated to sourcetree 1.9.5, fetch updates from remote, Merges are required. I select one of the files to be merged and press 'Launch External Tool'. In my SourceTree settings I have selected DiffMerge as the tool of choice.

Unfortunately DiffMerge is not spawned. Used to work before the last update.

Source Tree Git: System Git 2.0

fields.description:
Viewing the Working Copy in Tree View and with "No Staging" enabled.

Several files must have changed, preferably in different directories.

Selecting all changed files by clicking a shared parent, the commit succeeds, but when selecting some of the changed files one by one, the commit isn't always accepted and I get the error message: "Nothing to commit! (please select files)".
fields.summary: Can't always commit in git when "no staging" option and "tree view" is enabled

fields.description:
In the latest version, the status of the files are not automatically updated after changes are made to any source file. Pressing Command-R refreshes the status. 
Command-R must be pressed even after committing changes to refresh the status.

fields.summary: Desktop App crashes when opened

fields.description:
The file lists for staging in the Log view does not display the typical files available for staging when a filter is active in the "File Status" view, but rather shows files related to that filter.

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Make a change in your repo so that the modified file shows in the staging area of the Log view.
2. Switch to the File Status view and type in the name of a file which does not match your changed file. For example if you changed foo.txt then filter on bar.
3. Switch back to the Log view.
4. Select the "Uncommited Changes" item and look at the staging lists.

The Staged Files list will be blank and the Unstaged Files list no longer shows the modified files, but appears to have an exhaustive list of all the files in the repo.

To get the view back to normal you have to switch back to "File Status" and remove the filter string.
fields.summary: Filter from "File Status" view affects the Log view for staging

fields.description:
When using SourceTree 1.9.x for OSX against a Mecurial (hg) repository, SourceTree will preselect  all pending files when the repository is first opened.  This is rarely what I want, forcing me to deselect all files before doing anything else.

I know about "Commit Selected", and this is just a workflow issue that will be different for everyone, so I ask that you add an option to SourceTree's preferences to enable/disable the auto-selection of pending files.
fields.summary: Add option to disable preselection of pending files

fields.description:
When editing the message for a squashed commit, the textarea size causes bad line breaks in the existing message.

If a resizable message editing box is not possible, the textarea should allow for the same width as the line-length indicator in the main commit window.
fields.summary: Line breaks in Edit Message popup input

fields.description:
Issue:
A broken timeline display in SourceTree.

Steps to reproduce:
- Use a Stash server, who's system time is slightly behind the local system time.
- Make a commit on a feature branch and push it to the server, while already having a pull request in place.
- Merge the pull request, so that the merge commit happens earlier in server system time, than the commit that is being merged in client system time.

Expected results:
The line representation in Sourcetree should show the same results as calling git log --graph would on the command line.
Example: cabcb8e was merged as of deb9d23

Actual results:
The commit that has been merged does not appear to be merged. Instead from the merge, a line goes down all the way to the end of the scrollview and ends below the very first commit of the repository.
Example: cabcb8e does not appear to be merged as of deb9d23 when viewed in SourceTree.
fields.summary: Broken timeline after merging pull request in Stash (Slightly different system times)

fields.description:
Steps to reproduce the issue:

1. Open Sourcetree.
2. Go to: Sourcetree -> Preferences.
3. Try to close the window using either red button or CMD+W.
fields.summary: Preferences Panel don't close after opening.

fields.description:
It will be good to make a feature to apply certain part of stash, not only full stash. For instance, you can add in "detail stash window" (similar button, like it is in details Staged/Unstaged window for certain file) some button like "Apply hunk" and/or after pressing right mouse button in context menu add "Apply Selected Lines".
Outlined approximate place for button in followed image.
fields.summary: Increasing stash possibilities

fields.description:
Diff viewer seems to only display the first 20 selected files, with no indication that it stops at this limit.  I was bit by this when I selected a large number of modified files and didn't notice an unintended destructive change wasn't listed in the diff pane, due to the file being above 20+ selected in the modified file area.

I suppose solutions could be:
- Display all selected files (though this may have a performance consideration?)
- Indicate somewhere in the diff view that only 20 files are selected
- Add pagination controls to display shifting increments of 2- files in this view, so that I don't have to select smaller groups at a time to accomplish the same goal.
fields.summary: Diff Viewer limited to 20 files

fields.description:
Opening the Hosted Repositories window often creates a lot of requests to GitHub.  The API has a limit for each user and when it is reached, your login is denied as detailed in SRCTREE-2520.

Could you have SourceTree cache the info collected for the Hosted Repositories list instead of fetching it every time?  The cache info should be set to expire after a set time.  The cached time details could be shown at the top of the window next to the Refresh button.

P.S.  The GitHub API gives you access to the current rate limit and the next reset time [https://developer.github.com/v3/rate_limit/]. SourceTree should collect this info and limit itself from attempting a request if the limit has been reached.  If it has, the connection window should show this info and when the limit will be reset.
fields.summary: REQ: Cache Hosted Repository info

fields.description:
There are a few issues regarding the Login Error dialog window in SourceTree.

# If there is a failure to connect to GitHub due to API limitations, SourceTree reports this with a "Login Error" dialog window.  Since all of my GitHub repos are configured for SSH authentication and not username/passwords, this was very confusing. I had the Console app open for something else and I saw that SourceTree logged this error as a GitHub API limitation.\\ \\ "7/3/14 11:43:23.954 AM SourceTree: GitHub API call failed: API rate limit exceeded for InsomniacSoftware."\\ \\The error dialog window has a line that says "The remote service said: 'Login error'" which is not what the remote service actually said.  While the "Login Error" part is technically correct, if the dialog window had shown what the remote service actually said, it would have been more useful.\\ \\
# The GitHub API gives you access to the current rate limit and the next reset time [https://developer.github.com/v3/rate_limit/]. SourceTree should collect this info and limit itself from attempting a request if the limit has been reached.  If it has, the error window should show this info and when the limit will be reset.\\ \\
# Please include details of which bookmark/repo was the source of the server request.  I often have multiple SourceTree windows opened and I have no idea which one was the cause of the error.\\ \\
# When SourceTree shows the error dialog window, if the dialog is not dismissed and SourceTree attempts and fails to access the remote again, another dialog is created. (I had 6 of them on my screen!) This is bad UX and SourceTree should not access that same server again until the user has acknowledged the error dialog.\\ \\
# Regarding the last 2 items, I'd like to request that instead of using unattached error dialog windows that you use window sheets attached to whatever is the source of that call.  You are already using the window sheets for things like the repo's settings, the fetch/pull/push options, and the connection status.\\ \\
# If you are going to continue to use the unattached dialog windows, is there any way you can control which screen/Space they appear on?  In my situation from #4 above, I had no idea the error dialogs were even there as they were drawn onto a different Space, even different than all of the existing SourceTree windows.  (Space 1: full screen Chrome, 2: multiple SourceTree windows, 3: BBEdit and iTerm)  I was in Chrome when the connection errors happened but the SourceTree error dialog windows were drawn behind the iTerm window on Space 3.\\ \\
# If the user clicks in a regular SourceTree window but there is an error dialog being shown (somewhere), the system just beeps which is not very helpful.  Could you make the error dialog be pulled into the current Space and become the frontmost window?  As mentioned in the previous item, I had no idea where the error dialogs were.  I even tried using App Expose to show all of the SourceTree windows but that only shows on the current Space.  Only when I used Mission Control did I see the 6 cascading error dialog windows peeking out from behind the iTerm window.
fields.summary: Multiple Login Error dialog window issues

fields.description:
I have an existing remote entry of 'dotfiles' pointing to GitHub.  If I add another remote entry of 'dotfiles' that is on BitBucket, SourceTree accepts it and adds it to the Remotes page of the repo Settings (shows 2 entries, both named 'dotfiles').

However, upon clicking OK, the GitHub entry was mostly updated with the values for BitBucket.  The URL field was changed to BB but the lower Optional Extended Integration fields remained on the GH settings.

SourceTree should handle it by either
a. Disabling the OK button and show a warning text that the remote name is a duplicate
b. Automatically renaming the remote entry name (append a number or server name)

Side note: Sourcetree becomes very confused when this happens in regards to the remote's branches and status.  In my case, the GH repo is complete with files/folders/branches/tags/etc but the BB repo is empty.  Even after a fetch/pull of the remote repo, SourceTree still showed the same status.  I'm guessing that this is a local caching git issue though.
fields.summary: Improper handling of remotes with the same name

fields.description:
When setting/editing the remote name, if you use certain invalid characters, the remote entry disappears without error/warning.  

I had a remote repo entry called 'dotfiles/master' but that didn't specify which remote server it was using.  I edited the remote name to be "GH:dotfiles" and SourceTree accepted it.  Upon clicking the OK button, the remote entry disappeared.

SourceTree needs to warn or convert invalid characters to valid chars.  It already does this if you use a space in the remote name, which is converted to an underscore.
fields.summary: Handling of invalid chars in remote name

fields.description:
As a user I'd like to be able to pull from many selected repositories at one time.

This will avoid to open every repository individually and then pull from GIT.
Each repo may have some checkbox in Bookmarks view and after choosing it we can make batch pull (or even push and so on).
fields.summary: Pull from all repositories at one time

fields.description:
When I drag a file from un-staged to staged, the selection moves to the next un-staged file, instead of sticking with the selected file I just dragged. The experience is jarring, as generally I am reviewing changes in the diff pane, deciding what to drag up. As soon as I drag, the diff pane shows a different file making me feel like I just did something wrong.

I request that the selected file remain selected after dragging from one area to another.
fields.summary: Maintain focus on file after dragging

fields.description:
McIlroy-Hunt longest common subsequence is used when you not only want to see diff but also what was changed exactly in the lines that changed.

Here is example of diff from SourceTree that doesn't use LCS:

!no_lcs.png!

And here is example from "GitX-dev (rowanj fork)" that does:

!with_lcs.png!

I propose that SourceTree should implement LCS, as option. Implementation is rather simple and provided by myriads of free libraries if needed.
fields.summary: LCS Diff

fields.description:
Double clicking on a folder in the Tree View used to open the folder in the Finder. It no longer does anything.

I used the feature of opening folders in the Finder by double clicking it in the Tree View all of the time.
fields.summary: Double Click Folder does nothing, used to open in Finder

fields.description: Before 1.9 it was possible to list files as Column View (in addition to flat and tree views). I miss this option since it was easier to drill down when viewing "All files" to find the log for a particular unchanged file.
fields.summary: Bring back column view in file list

fields.description:
Allow SourceTree to work with git-crypt to allow for encrypted files in repos.

https://github.com/AGWA/git-crypt
fields.summary: Make SourceTree work with git-crypt

fields.description:
Sometimes I forget to clear a search before switching from Sourcetree to another application. It often takes me a moment to realize that the persistent search is preventing me from seeing any files in the working copy view.

It would be very helpful to have a clear indication in the working copy view (and the change set view) that it is empty because there are no search results.
fields.summary: Clear indication of empty search results

fields.description:
There is one case when working copy does not show changed files anymore after committing files:

1) When files are staged and ready to commit, right click the file and select "Commit...".
2) After I confirm my commit the working copy does not refresh anymore. The sprocket near the staged files keeps spinning, but it doesn't show any changed files anymore, even when the number next to "Working copy" refreshes the amount of changed files.

I need to re-open the repository window to show my changed files again.
fields.summary: Working copy does not refresh anymore after committing files

fields.description:
Occasionally when performing a git commit operation, SourceTree will display the "Committing" dialog box with the animated barber-pole, but it does not finish. After a couple of minutes of waiting, I have to Force Quit SourceTree.

When I retry the same operation from the command line, using "git commit", it works fine.

In SourceTree's preferences, I have it set to use System Git version 1.8.5.2

Some example console log entries for the times that this occurred are available here: https://gist.github.com/kristopherjohnson/d6f0bfaeadaa361054ff

I have seen this behavior with multiple versions of SourceTree, but it seems to have become much more frequent with the 1.9.4.1 update.

I think I have only seen this behavior with a commit operation. I don't think I've seen it happen with other git operations (push, pull, etc.).
fields.summary: SourceTree does not complete commit operation

fields.description:
Currently by the end of the page [https://www.atlassian.com/software/sourcetree/overview] there is a link that leads to a SourceTree Documentation. This link currently takes to the [SourceTree Knowledge Base|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/SOURCETREEKB/SourceTree+Knowledge+Base+Home].

Some users would like to have a manual/tutorial that guides at least through the basics of SourceTree.

I've found some useful information in [this Answers topic|https://answers.atlassian.com/questions/149750/git-tutorial-using-sourcetree], which mentions a git tutorial ([http://www.atlassian.com/git]) that may should be referenced in the documentation, as well as a "SourceTree Help" that is included in the Mac version.

Summarizing, the suggestion is basically to have a documentation exposing SourceTree functionality and basic steps.
fields.summary: Include manual/tutorial for beginners in the SourceTree Documentation

fields.description: It sure would be nice if SourceTree would remember and restore the UI sash positions when the repository is opened again.  The first thing I have to do after opening a project is adjust the main horizontal sash and the vertical sash in the bottom section.  In fact, the botom sash usually starts out scrunched so far to the left that the panel is useless in its initial state.
fields.summary: Restore sash positions

fields.description:
I have an unstaged change to my Xcode .pbxproj file. In the right "diff" view, it shows no changes. See this screenshot: https://www.dropbox.com/s/7x605pagkgvh6e8/Screenshot%202014-06-24%2014.33.05.png

Previous versions used to do this, I'm sure.
fields.summary: .pbxproj files do not show diffs

fields.description:
Currently on the command line I can delete multiple local branches using something like {{git branch | grep -v "master" | xargs git branch -D}}. In Sourcetree, I can only delete one at a time.

I would like to be able to select multiple branches, right click, and delete the selected branches.
fields.summary: Clean up local branches

fields.description:
h2. Now

When view a stash, by select one sub-item of "STASHES" in left panel, it simply expand all diffs. With some manually and auto generated editions mixed up, it is difficult to locate the key point.

h2. Want

h3. Choice 1 - Fold

User can manually fold the diff of each file. It is the beautiful, but maybe less handy. Because if there is too many files, user may need to click several times to view the last one.

h3. Choice 2 - List

Just like the design of view a commit. We can seperate a file list panel from diff view. It is easy to understand and use, but may waste some space of view port.
fields.summary: View the diff of each files in stashes

fields.description:
When viewing command history, the timestamp next to each entry appears to be ambiguous, it looks like it is in 24 hour format, having a leading zero, but it is actually 12 hour format.

To demonstrate, I just did a branch switch at *16*:28:26, and this was logged as: _Switching branch \[21/06/2014 *04*:28:26\]_

It should read: _Switching branch \[21/06/2014 *16*:28:26\]_
fields.summary: Command History timestamp hour format incorrect

fields.description:
When opening the preferences dialog from SourceTree > Preferences, the window cannot be close with cmd+w or by clicking the red close button in top left.

Some settings are saved regardless, but the one in particular that I am trying to save (Preferences > Git > Push branches) will not save apparently. I am trying to change the drop down to upstream. it will not save and the window will not close.

Exception From Console.app

fields.summary: Preferences Dialog Will Not Close And Settings Not Saved

fields.description:
I'm trying to piece together the full history of a library of code that was modified across 3 larger projects.

Imported from SVN into a single git repo with each project as a branch and then Cherry Picking is giving me the history tree structure I want. 

But the Date column of Log view is showing the new Commit Date (today) instead of the original Date (2012-2013). Both dates are shown in the commit message area.

Could you add a separate, sortable column for original Date value and rename the current Date column to Commit Date since that is what it is referred to in the commit message area.
fields.summary: Log View columns for both Date and Commit Date

fields.description:
It'd be nice if SourceTree automatically fetched from remotes when a repo is opened from the bookmarks browser, and there was a visible indication that a fetch was initiated in the background.

It's kind of annoying when there's no indication if there are/aren't actually new commits. I always have to fetch manually to confirm. It would be very useful to have a persistent indicator like "last fetched 4.3 minutes ago" so you'd always know the state.
fields.summary: Automatically fetch when repo is opened

fields.description:
As of now, applying a stash is an all-or-nothing operation; it would be nice to be able to apply just some of the stash to the working tree. Either individual hunks, or (ideally) at granularity selected by the user, eg. select a region with the mouse and select "apply to working tree".

It would be great also to see a list of affected files, just like the view for commits.
fields.summary: Finer-grained application of stashes

fields.description: See attached screenshot
fields.summary: Long branch name overlaps cancel button in commit dialog

fields.description:
Due to the nature of our development environment, I find myself needing to keep a small handful of stashed change sets around permanently. They get applied when I need those changes and then the changes get reverted once I'm done, but the stashes get reused over and over again.

It would be very handy to be able to pin or otherwise lock those stashes such that:

1. the default is to NOT delete the stash when applying
2. the stash cannot be deleted without first unpinning it
fields.summary: Pinnable stashes

fields.description: In the prior version, it was very easy to change the context settings temporarily to see more or less context. With the recent big update, those settings are hidden in another menu and much harder to toggle quickly.
fields.summary: Please bring the context choices (# of lines) back to the toolbar

fields.summary: Crash with SIGILL after pulling update

fields.description:
This is a long standing issue with Sourcetree. When GIT commands are executed from the command line that push content to a remote repo, the icon is not updated in sourcetree to reflect that. This is even while the actual tag list IS updated, the icon does not track. 

Scenario:

- Make a change to working copy
- Commit the change through sourcetree without pushing to remote
- Externally through command line push the change
- Return to sourcetree

result
- Sourcetree shows 1 commit badge on push icon still waiting to be pushed
fields.summary: Push Icon is not maintained

fields.description: Changed the font size preferences for diff and the pref window won't close.
fields.summary: Can't close preferences window

fields.description:
My ~/.ssh/config file uses the following parameters for persistent connections:

    ControlMaster auto
    ControlPath /tmp/ssh_mux_%h_%p_%r
    ControlPersist 2h

However, when I try and perform any operation that happens after a connection has expired (e.g. after my mac has been sleeping for 20mins+), it crashes SourceTree and requires a Force Quit to get it working again. After that it works fine.

Persistent connections are something of a must for us as we run our stash on AWS and it can take a while to initiate a connection.

(This bug has been affecting me for ages - about two years - but it has taken me this long to narrow down the cause to the ssh configuration)
fields.summary: SourceTree crashes on ssh+git connections with ControlPersist

fields.description:
So before the revamp of the staging and commit flow, the remote chosen to 'push changes immediately to..' seemed to be either the last remote I committed to or the first remote listed in the git config file.

Now it seems to get stuck on just the first remote listed in the remotes list on the left panel.  There is no  way to sort or prioritize the list of remotes in Sourcetree (that I can find) so no way to tell it to always pick 'origin' or something.

This should either be configurable with some priority or matching rules or just go off the .git/config ordering like I think it used to.

You can see in the screenshots I attached, mine is stuck on corey/master most likely since the list of remotes is ordered alphabetically and 'corey' is first.  You can see that the 'corey' remote is specified much later in the .git/config file and should not be chosen all the time as the remote I would push to normally.

Thanks!
fields.summary: Commit: push changes immediately to...picks wrong remote

fields.description:
To reproduce:
1. Push the "Pull" button in the toolbar when there is a large volume of new data on the default remote.
2. Push "Ok" in the resulting dialog before the changes are listed.
3. While Sourcetree is showing the indeterminate progress bar and message about listing changes, switch to another Application.
4. Wait until Sourcetree starts actually pulling changes.

Expected results:
Sourcetree starts pulling changes, and then finishes without drawing too much attention to itself.

Actual results:
Sourcetree starts bouncing its Dock icon as soon as it starts actually pulling changes, and does not stop bouncing it until it is finished or the user gives Sourcetree focus before it is finished.

Notes:
I don't think there's any need for Sourcetree to bounce its icon in this edge case, since it does not provide any notification of being finished in other cases.
fields.summary: Dock icon bounces continuously during pull

fields.description:
I'm on an iOS project that uses Cocoapods as a dependency manager (this setup is rather common). Whenever the pods are updated, the project.pbxproj file is changed considerably. This seems to cause SourceTree to hang while trying to calculate the diff.

Generally, when a file with a large diff is selected, the entire UI freezes for multiple tens of seconds and the beach ball of death shows up. The only way out is to force kill the app, or wait for a long time until the diff calculation has finished.

This bug also locks the UI when I select files and add them to the staging area. Possibly, because the file in question happens to be at the bottom. It makes SourceTree unbearably slow and painful to use.

My work around for now involves going straight to console, add the file manually with "git add" and then switch back to SourceTree. "git add" doesn't need to present a diff, so it's blazingly fast (<<1sec)

I've attached the file that's causing the issue.

Would be nice if the diffing could move into the background and allow switching files even when the diff has not been calculated yet.
fields.summary: Clicking on a file with a large diff freezes entire UI

fields.description: It does a weird diff. Look at the screenshot
fields.summary: Blank PHP file detected as Binary file

fields.description:
h3.Steps to reproduce
# Modify a file in two folders: FolderA and FolderB
# Access SourceTree Working Copy staging area
# Set Tree View for the staging area
# Collapse FolderA to hide the modified file in FolderA
# Stage the modified file in FolderB
Staging Area refresh after staging the file and expand FolderA to show the modified file

SourceTree shouldn't have expand FolderA and maintain the collapse state
fields.summary: Maintaining the State of the Tree View

fields.description:
I was setting up a new user with SourceTree (no prior experience with version control), and she used the "remove" button to delete files that were in unknown state without going to the Finder. This seems reasonable, and there's even a dialog that tries to prevent foot-shooting. Nice.

What happened next was funny though: the file then showed up in the status pane as "missing" even though it had gone from "unknown" to being deleted (which means it was just gone, nothing should have been in the dirstate).
fields.summary: Using "remove" action on a file in "unknown" state confuses SourceTree's copy of dirstate

fields.description: Files committed are not sorted in filename order. Choosing "Sort by filename" results in a "Sort by Pathname" sorting. This is problematic on large commits on multi-module projects.
fields.summary: Sort on filename non-functional in log view

fields.description:
This started a few versions back. There are multiple files in a commit, but SourceTree only shows the first one.  

Screenshots show source tree vs. magit for commit a004f2f
fields.summary: Log View only shows one file per commit
Please, come back to MAS, break sandbox restrictions =)

fields.description:
Whenever I try to discard a hunk I get:
'patch' failed with code 1:''

I've also tried with 3.0+20140529 System Mercurial too, and that gives the same error.

If I try to discard a single line, I get:
{quote}
Applying a patch to the working folder failed - the most likely reason for this is that the state of the file(s) in your working folder have altered too much for the patch process to be able to complete successfully.

Please make the changes manually instead.
{quote}

Seems the issue has been around since 1.3?
https://twitter.com/aras_p/status/168721126590124032
fields.summary: Discard hunk/line results in 'patch' failed with code 1:''

fields.description: Currently one has to edit a file to see it in source tree. Which means, if you have to remove a file, you first need to edit and then remove. 2 steps. Or you can use the command line.
fields.summary: Ability to browse source directory

fields.description:
One really great feature that perforce provides is, time lapse view for files. 

It lets you slide through all revisions for any particular file. It allows you to select sections in the file and will highlight which revision it was introduced in. 

This helps debug changes in a larger team and track down issues. I feel a feature like this will make source tree stand out!
fields.summary: Time Lapse View

fields.description: After installing the latest update on mac, source tree has become very sluggish. Simply switching to a branch takes 3-5 secs.
fields.summary: Sluggish on the latest update

fields.summary: SourceTree crashes

fields.description:
Once in a detached HEAD state, SourceTree stops showing any of the commits in the log and displays a alert window stating {{'git log' failed with code 128:'fatal: bad revision '(detached from 1a88246)'}}.

Version is {{1.9.4.1}}.
fields.summary: 'Current Branch' log filter on detached HEAD causes git error
